image.altText: Dutton walks through a crowd wearing Liberal blue shirts.

items.synopsis: A commitment by Liberal Party leader Peter Dutton to hold a second referendum on Indigenous recognition has been rubbished by one of the leading conservative Voice campaigners.

title.children: Dutton criticised by 'Liberals for Yes' group over pledge for second Indigenous recognition referendum

image.altText: Two brunette women sit on the floor of a lounge room looking at each other smiling while patting a dog that lay on the ground

image.altText: A blonde white man wears a pink shirt, while riding in the back of a pink car driven by a white blonde woman in a pink outfit.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Barbie becomes the year's highest-grossing film, Casey Donovan stranded at Burning Man. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The AFL has confirmed American rock band KISS will be the pre-game entertainment for this year's grand final. The band is currently touring as part of their global End of the World tour. The announcement comes after Crowded House pulled out of the performance last month. The band says it will be an honour to perform on the AFL's biggest day of the year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: KISS to perform at AFL grand final

children.content: The
AFL
has confirmed American rock band
KISS
will be the pre-game entertainment for this year's grand final.
The band is currently touring as part of their global End of the World tour.
The announcement comes after
Crowded House
pulled out of the performance last month.
The band says it will be an honour to perform on the AFL's biggest day of the year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-6 is set to splashdown today, wrapping up a nearly six-month science mission. The Dragon spacecraft, named Endeavour, will undock, depart the space station, and return important and time-sensitive research to Earth, Nasa says. NASA astronauts Stephen Bowen and Woody Hoburg, United Arab Emirates astronaut Sultan Alneyadi, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Andrey Fedyaev are onboard. The spacecraft will splash down at one of seven targeted landing zones in the Atlantic Ocean or Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Florida.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coming up today: NASA’s SpaceX to splashdown to Earth

children.content: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-6 is set to splashdown today, wrapping up a nearly six-month science mission.
The Dragon spacecraft, named Endeavour, will undock, depart the space station, and return important and time-sensitive research to Earth, Nasa says.
NASA astronauts Stephen Bowen and Woody Hoburg, United Arab Emirates astronaut Sultan Alneyadi, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Andrey Fedyaev are onboard.
The spacecraft will splash down at one of seven targeted landing zones in the Atlantic Ocean or Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Florida.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New industrial relations legislation will be introduced to parliament today, which the government says will close loopholes that currently lead to unfair pay and conditions. Political reporter Evelyn Manfield explains what's being debated: This is the second tranche of the government's industrial relations reform. Under the change, the Fair Work Act would be amended to close a so-called loophole where an employer and employees have agreed through an enterprise agreement to a particular rate of pay, but then that pay is undercut when the employer brings in different workers through labour hire. The bill is also promising to introduce greater protections for gig economy workers and casuals, and increase penalties for wage theft. But business groups are opposing the changes, arguing they add complexity and will drive up costs. Political reporter Stephanie Borys was on News Breakfast earlier and said the bill will be debated for four weeks in the House of Representatives before it goes to the Senate where the government needs to find the numbers from the Greens and crossbench to get it through.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New industrial relations legislation to be introduced to parliament

image.altText: Man in royal outfit and crown

items.synopsis: With the one-year anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II's death approaching, royal fans took to Buckingham Palace to commemorate with a parade of her favourite breed of dogs.

title.children: 'Can't see a better way to remember her': Corgis dress in royal best for late queen

items.synopsis: The federal government extends its national rollout of endometriosis and pelvic pain clinics in a bid to improve diagnosis times and treatment.

title.children: New endometriosis clinics announced for Adelaide, Sydney

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Local shares are likely to make gains with company profits, inventories, and wages data due mid-morning. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX looks set to rise, US Fed expected to pause interest rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: European stocks steadied, ending the session flat as a decline in luxury and auto shares was offset by gains in mining and healthcare. The STOXX 600 posted its biggest weekly gain since mid-July. The pan-European STOXX 600 index lost 0.01 per cent and MSCI's gauge of stocks across the globe gained 0.1 per cent. Oil prices jumped on Friday, touching their highest level in over seven months, driven by expectations of tightening supply. Gold prices wavered throughout the session but were last slightly higher.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What about in Europe

children.content: European stocks steadied
, ending the session flat as a decline in luxury and auto shares was offset by gains in mining and healthcare.
The STOXX 600 posted its
biggest weekly gain since mid-July
The pan-European STOXX 600 index lost 0.01 per cent and MSCI's gauge of stocks across the globe gained 0.1 per cent.
Oil prices jumped on Friday, touching their highest level in over seven months, driven by expectations of tightening supply.
Gold prices wavered throughout the session but were last slightly higher.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US stock indexes settled for a mixed close on Friday after a US jobs report showed an uptick in unemployment, cementing expectations that the Federal Reserve will let interest rates stand at its September meeting. The three major indexes gave up earlier advances, losing momentum as the session progressed and investors digested the data ahead of the long US holiday weekend. The S & P 500 and the Dow ended modestly green, while the tech-laded Nasdaq closed nearly unchanged. All three indexes notched gains on the week. "Today, people are coasting into the holiday weekend with relief that the job numbers were solid," said Ryan Detrick, chief market strategist at Carson Group in Omaha. "There are signs of the economy slowing, which is what the Fed wants to see," Detrick added. "It likely opens the door for no rate hike at the next Fed meeting in three weeks." The Labor Department's payrolls report showed the US economy added more jobs than expected last month, but the rising unemployment and participation rates, along with a welcome cool-down in average hourly wage growth, solidified expectations that the Fed will let key interest rates stand this month. Financial markets are pricing in a 93 per cent likelihood of such a pause this month, according to CME's FedWatch tool. But what the Fed will do beyond September remains an open question.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What happened on Wall Street

children.content: US stock indexes settled for a mixed close on Friday after a US jobs report showed an uptick in unemployment, cementing expectations that the Federal Reserve will let interest rates stand at its September meeting.
The three major indexes gave up earlier advances
, losing momentum as the session progressed and investors digested the data ahead of the long US holiday weekend.
The S
P 500 and the Dow ended modestly green, while the tech-laded Nasdaq closed nearly unchanged.
All three indexes notched gains on the week.
"Today, people are coasting into the holiday weekend with relief that the job numbers were solid," said Ryan Detrick, chief market strategist at Carson Group in Omaha.
"There are signs of the economy slowing, which is what the Fed wants to see," Detrick added. "It likely opens the door for no rate hike at the next Fed meeting in three weeks."
The Labor Department's payrolls report showed
the US economy added more jobs than expected last month
, but the rising unemployment and participation rates, along with a welcome cool-down in average hourly wage growth, solidified expectations that the Fed will let key interest rates stand this month.
Financial markets are pricing in
a 93 per cent likelihood
of such a pause this month, according to CME's FedWatch tool.
But what the Fed will do beyond September remains an open question.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello, Sam Yang here to bring you through the day's market action. And with ASX futures pointing higher, it could be a good start to the week for the local share market in just over an hour's time. It follows US markets inching higher on Friday, as traders digested the jobs data ahead of the long US holiday weekend. Wall Street is closed today for Labor Day. On the local front, the ABS will release company profits, inventories, and wages at 11.30am AEST — so stick around through the day for all the latest!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Good morning

company profits, inventories, and wages
at 11.30am

title.children: On dark days, through chronic illness, hunting awe has saved me. It can transform your life, too
